Personalized Federated Learning via Convex Clustering

Aleksandar Armacki Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA
Email: {aarmacki, soummyak}@andrew.cmu.edu Dragana Bajovic Faculty of Technical Sciences, University of Novi Sad, Novi Sad, Serbia
Email: dbajovic@uns.ac.rs Dusan Jakovetic Faculty of Sciences, University of Novi Sad, Novi Sad, Serbia
Email: dusan.jakovetic@dmi.uns.ac.rs Soummya Kar Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA
Email: {aarmacki, soummyak}@andrew.cmu.edu
Abstract

We propose a parametric family of algorithms for personalized federated learning with locally convex user costs. The proposed framework is based on a generalization of convex clustering in which the differences between different usersâ€™ models are penalized via a sum-of-norms penalty, weighted by a penalty parameterÂ Î»ğœ†\lambda. The proposed approach enables â€œautomaticâ€ model clustering, without prior knowledge of the hidden cluster structure, nor the number of clusters. Analytical bounds on the weight parameter, that lead to simultaneous personalization, generalization and automatic model clustering are provided. The solution to the formulated problem enables personalization, by providing different models across different clusters, and generalization, by providing models different than the per-user models computed in isolation. We then provide an efficient algorithm based on the Parallel Direction Method of Multipliers (PDMM) to solve the proposed formulation in a federated server-users setting. Numerical experiments corroborate our findings. As an interesting byproduct, our results provide several generalizations to convex clustering.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a paradigm in which many users collaborate, with the goal of learning a joint model [1]. Each user has a local dataset, with private and possibly sensitive data. The data distribution across users is typically highly heterogeneous. â€ â€ The work of D. Bajovic is supported by the European Unionâ€™s Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation program under grant agreement No 957337. The work of A. Armacki and S. Kar was partially supported by the National Science Foundation under grant CNS-1837607. This paper reflects only the authorsâ€™ views and the European Commission cannot be held responsible for any use which may be made of the information contained therein.

A federated learning system can have a huge amount of users, wherein each user contributes with a proportionally small local dataset. Therefore, the federation provides users with the benefit of training on the joint data, effectively offering broader knowledge and better generalization. However, due to the highly heterogeneous nature of the data, it is nontrivial to design a FL system where individual users achieve better performance though the federation when compared with models trained on their own local data. In fact, the authors inÂ [2] show that in many tasks, users may actually not benefit from participating in federated learning. The globally trained model underperforms on their local data, compared to the model solely trained on the local data. Moreover, applying privacy preserving techniques further deteriorates the performance. On the other hand, users with very small datasets suffer from overfitting and poor generalization of models trained only on their local data.

To amend these problems and reap the benefits of both worlds â€“ the abundance of data and better learning that the federation offers, as well as adapting the models to perform well on the local data, personalized federated learning is introduced. Unlike the standard federated learning, the goal of personalized federated learning is to learn multiple models. In particular, let Nğ‘N be the number of participating users, with f:â„dâ†¦â„:ğ‘“maps-tosuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f:\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R} a given cost function. Then, the goal of standard FL is to solve

argâ€‹minxâˆˆâ„dâ¡Fglobalâ€‹(x)=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(x),subscriptargminğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ¹globalğ‘¥1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F_{\text{global}}(x)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x), (1)

where fiâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥f_{i}(x) is the cost function fğ‘“f evaluated on the local dataset of the iğ‘–i-th user. Contrary to this approach, the (broad) goal of personalized FL is to learn Nğ‘N models, by solving

argâ€‹minx1,â€¦,xNâˆˆâ„dâ¡Flocalâ€‹(x1,â€¦,xN)=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(xi),subscriptargminsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ¹localsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{x_{1},\ldots,x_{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F_{\text{local}}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{N})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i}), (2)

subject to appropriately defined constraints. Depending on the constraints imposed and the approach taken to solving (2), the literature on personalized FL adopts different approaches to personalization, including multi-task learning [3], [4], fine-tuning [5], [6], knowledge distillation [7], [8], [9], [10] and clustering-based approaches [11], [12], [13].

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to personalized federated learning that enables simultaneous personalization, generalization, and model clustering. The approach is based on the following novel personalized FL (convex problem) formulation:

argâ€‹minx1,â€¦,xNâˆˆâ„dâ¡Fâ€‹(x1,â€¦,xN)=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(xi)+Î»â€‹âˆ‘jâ‰ iâ€–xiâˆ’xjâ€–,subscriptargminsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğœ†subscriptğ‘—ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{x_{1},\ldots,x_{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F(x_{1},\ldots,x_{N})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i})+\lambda\sum_{j\neq i}\|x_{i}-x_{j}\|, (3)

where Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0 is a penalty parameter, and âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥\|\cdot\| stands for the Euclidean norm. Compared withÂ (2), the formulationÂ (3) has a regularization term controlled withÂ Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0, that penalizes the differences between the local nodesâ€™ solutions via a sum-of-norms penalty.

FormulationÂ (3) may be seen as a generalization of convex clustering, e.g.,Â [14], where, instead of the (quadratic) distance functions, which penalize the departure from a local data point, we use arbitrary convex local losses.

ProblemÂ (3) is also related with the personalized FL formulation inÂ [15], which, instead of the sum of norms of pairwise distances uses the sum of squared norms of distances of local solutions to their average. As we show in the paper, although the two formulations are resembling, the solution structures of the two formulations are qualitatively very different.

Specifically, as we show in the paper, the solution toÂ (3) has several interesting properties, which, to the best of our knowledge, are not (jointly) exhibited with any of the previous personalized FL formulations. Namely, a solution toÂ (3) has a clustered structure: depending on the penalty parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda and similarity of the local functions, local solutions xiâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†x_{i}^{\star} of (3) are equal across certain usersâ€™ groups (clusters). The number of groups (clusters) Kğ¾K is automatically determined as part of the solution. To further illustrate benefits of this feature, suppose that the users exhibit an (unknown) clustered structure such that each userâ€™s data within a cluster comes from the same distribution, while the distributions that correspond to different clusters are mutually different. If the different clustersâ€™ distributions are sufficiently far apart, the proposed method (3) uncovers the unknown cluster structure and hence allocates the same models to all users within the same cluster. This allows within-cluster generalization, i.e., users to effectively enlarge their training data by harnessing data of all users from the same cluster. In addition, depending on the distance between the different clustersâ€™ distributions, the method (3) allows for a controlled across-clusters generalization; intuitively, it allows a user to harness data from another clustersâ€™ distribution, but with a different (reduced) â€weightâ€ when compared to within-cluster data. If, at an extreme, the difference between different clustersâ€™ distributions is negligible (but this information is unknown), then users should clearly use the global model (1). This is again captured by (3), because (as shown in the paper) it matches (1) for Î»ğœ†\lambda above a threshold.

In summary, our contributions are the following: First, we propose a novel formulation for personalized federated learningÂ (3), the solution of which has a clustering structure while at the same time preserving generalization abilities.

Second, we provide a condition on the penalty parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda, with theoretical guarantees, for discovering the â€œhidden structureâ€ underlying the models; this condition is expressed in terms of the well-established diversity of the local functions, hence making a strong connection and justifying analytically the use of this quantity.

Third, the proposed solution â€automaticallyâ€ determines the number of models Kğ¾K, i.e., Kğ¾K need not be known in advance.

Fourth, we provide an efficient algorithm to solve the novel personalized learning formulationÂ (3) in a federated server-client setting that is based upon the Parallel Direction Method of Multipliers (PDMM)Â [16].

Finally, we demonstrate by simulation examples, on a supervized binary classification problem, that the proposed solution exhibits 1)1) generalization, i.e., improves testing accuracy with respect to the users models trained in isolation; 2)2) personalization, i.e., improves testing accuracy with respect to the global FL model (1); and 3)3) achieves a comparable (or better) generalization and personalization (in the sense of 1)1) and 2)2)) than [4], while at the same time uncovering cluster structure, hence reducing the number of distinct models from Nğ‘N to Kğ¾K.

With respect to existing personalized FL approaches discussed above, the works [11, 12, 13, 10] also account for usersâ€™ clustering in a certain way, but very differently from our approach. Most notably, existing approaches aim to uncover â€œcluster identitiesâ€ first and subsequently provide loss minimizations across cluster groups in isolation from other groups. This within-clusters isolation may reduce overall generalization ability of the models. In contrast, the proposed approach allows also for across-clusters generalization that is further controlled by the penalty parameterÂ Î»ğœ†\lambda. It is worth noting that reference [17] introduces formulation similar to (3), but in a different context of distributed consensus optimization. Most importantly, they are only concerned with the question when (3) matches (1), i.e., when (3) leads to a global consensus across local models; they are not concerned, nor they study personalization (clustering) abilities of (3).

Our results are also of direct interest to convex clustering, e.g.,Â [14], as they provide recovery guarantees for generalized convex clustering, when the squared quadratic loss fiâ€‹(x):=â€–xiâˆ’aiâ€–2assignsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–2f_{i}(x):=\|x_{i}-a_{i}\|^{2} per data pointÂ aiâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘‘a_{i}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} is replaced with an arbitrary differentiable convex loss, e.g., the Huber loss.

Paper organization. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section II describes the problem of interest and outlines the assumptions used in the analysis. Section III presents the recovery guarantees of the method. Section IV outlines an efficient algorithm for solving the proposed problem in the federated setting. Section V presents numerical experiments, and Section VI concludes the paper. The next paragraph introduces the notation used throughout the paper.

II Problem formulation

Consider a collection of Nğ‘N users, i=1,â€¦,Nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘i=1,\ldots,N, that participate in a federated learning activity. Each user iğ‘–i holds a function fi:â„dâ†’â„:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f_{i}:\,{\mathbb{R}}^{d}\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}}. Function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} may correspond, e.g., to an empirical loss with respect to the local data set available at userÂ iğ‘–i. We make the following assumptions throughout the paper.

Assumption 1.

For each i=1,â€¦,Nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘i=1,\ldots,N, function fi:â„dâ†’â„:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f_{i}:\,{\mathbb{R}}^{d}\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}} is convex and coercive, i.e., fiâ€‹(x)â†’+âˆâ†’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥f_{i}(x)\rightarrow+\infty whenever â€–xâ€–â†’+âˆâ†’normğ‘¥\|x\|\rightarrow+\infty.

Assumption 2.

For each i=1,â€¦,Nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘i=1,\ldots,N, function fi:â„dâ†’â„:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f_{i}:\,{\mathbb{R}}^{d}\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}} has Lipschitz continuous gradients, i.e. the following holds

â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(y)â€–â‰¤Lâ€‹â€–xâˆ’yâ€–,forâ€‹allâ€‹x,yâˆˆâ„d.formulae-sequencenormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¦ğ¿normğ‘¥ğ‘¦forallğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{i}(y)\|\leq L\|x-y\|,\>\mathrm{for\,all\,}\>x,y\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}.

Note that, under the above assumptions, problemsÂ (1) andÂ (3) are solvable. We denote by yâ‹†âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptğ‘¦â‹†superscriptâ„ğ‘‘y^{\star}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} a solution toÂ (1) and by {xiâ‹†}superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†\{x_{i}^{\star}\}, i=1,â€¦,Nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘i=1,\ldots,N, xiâ‹†âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x_{i}^{\star}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, a solution toÂ (3).

There are many machine learning models that satisfy AssumptionsÂ 1 andÂ 2, such as supervized binary classification problems studied in Section V.

The high-level goal in personalized federated learning is that each user iğ‘–i finds a local model, say xiâˆ™âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–âˆ™superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x_{i}^{\bullet}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, that performs well on the local data (i.e., the value fiâ€‹(xiâˆ™)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–âˆ™f_{i}(x_{i}^{\bullet}) is low), but that also exhibits a generalization ability with respect to data available at other usersÂ jâ‰ iğ‘—ğ‘–j\neq i. In addition, a desirable feature of personalized federated learning is that the users are able to classify other users into two categories. The first category corresponds to those users jâˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,N}ğ‘—12â€¦ğ‘j\in\{1,2,\ldots,N\} that have similar data (similar fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j}â€™s) to their own; the second category corresponds to those users whose local data is â€œsufficiently differentâ€ from theirs. With this classification in place, each user iğ‘–i can fully harness the data from â€œsimilar usersâ€ for an improved personalization while avoiding overfitting; e.g., when userÂ iğ‘–i has a very few data points of its own, it effectively enlarges its data set while preserving personalization. On the other hand, the data from â€œsufficiently different usersâ€ should still be harnessed in a controlled way to further improve generalization abilities.

To account for the effects above, we provide a novel personalized learning formulation, where each user iğ‘–i wants to obtain the local model xiâ‹†âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x_{i}^{\star}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} such that xâ‹†:=((x1â‹†)âŠ¤,â€¦,(xNâ‹†)âŠ¤)âŠ¤âˆˆâ„Nâ€‹dassignsuperscriptğ‘¥â‹†superscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1â‹†topâ€¦superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘â‹†toptopsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘‘x^{\star}:=((x_{1}^{\star})^{\top},\ldots,(x_{N}^{\star})^{\top})^{\top}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{N\,d} is a minimizer ofÂ (3), where Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0 is a tuning parameter. Intuitively, the term âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(xi)superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i}) forces the local models xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}â€™s to behave well with respect to local costs fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}â€™s; the term Î»â€‹âˆ‘jâ‰ iâ€–xiâˆ’xjâ€–ğœ†subscriptğ‘—ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—\lambda\,\sum_{j\neq i}\|x_{i}-x_{j}\| makes the local models be mutually close, hence enabling generalization. The penalization term âˆ‘jâ‰ iâ€–xiâˆ’xjâ€–subscriptğ‘—ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—\sum_{j\neq i}\|x_{i}-x_{j}\| is known to enforce sparsity in other contexts, in the sense that it forces many of the xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}â€™s to be mutually equal at a solution of (3).

It is interesting to compare our novel formulation (3) with the personalized federated learning formulation in [4]:

argâ€‹minx1,â€¦,xNâˆˆâ„dâ¡1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(xi)+Î³â€‹âˆ‘jâ‰ iâ€–xiâˆ’xjâ€–2,subscriptargminsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ›¾subscriptğ‘—ğ‘–superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—2\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{x_{1},\ldots,x_{N}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i})+\gamma\sum_{j\neq i}\|x_{i}-x_{j}\|^{2}, (4)

where Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0 is a penalty parameter.

The difference of (4) with respect to (3) is that, in (4), the differences of local models xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} and xjsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—x_{j} are penalized via the squared Euclidean norm, while with our formulation, the 2-norm appears without squares. There are several important implications of this difference with respect to the resulting personalized learning models. Most importantly, in contrast with (3), formulation (4) in general does not lead to model clustering for any Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0. In addition, as a side comment, the solutions to (1) and (4) are in general mutually different for any Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0 (in the sense that the solution {yiâ‹†}superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–â‹†\{y_{i}^{\star}\} to (4) does not obey yiâ‹†=yjâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–â‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—â‹†y_{i}^{\star}=y_{j}^{\star}, for all i,jğ‘–ğ‘—i,j, irrespective of the choice of Î»ğœ†\lambda). In contrast, with (3), we recover global model learning as in (1) for Î»>Î»^ğœ†^ğœ†\lambda>\widehat{\lambda}â€ â€ This can be easily seen based on Theorem 1 in [17]..

We also connect (3) with convex clustering. Convex clustering, e.g.Â [14], is an appealing method to cluster Nğ‘N data points aiâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘‘a_{i}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d}, i=1,â€¦,Nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘i=1,\ldots,N. The method corresponds to solving problem (3) with fiâ€‹(x)=12â€‹â€–xâˆ’aiâ€–2subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥12superscriptnormğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘–2f_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{2}\|x-a_{i}\|^{2}. Intuitively, to each data point iğ‘–i, we associate a candidate cluster center xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}, and then we enforce a (soft) constraint that many xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}â€™s should be mutually equal. There are several efficient algorithms and cluster recovery guarantees results available for convex clustering, but only when fiâ€‹(x)=12â€‹â€–xâˆ’aiâ€–2subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥12superscriptnormğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘–2f_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{2}\|x-a_{i}\|^{2}. Our results make a direct generalization of convex clustering to other loss metrics, e.g., the â€œdistanceâ€ of a candidate cluster xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} from data point aisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–a_{i} may be measured through the Huber loss.

Remark 1.

Note that TheoremÂ 1 guarantees that at least one solution ofÂ (3) exhibits the clustered structure with respect to partitionÂ C1,â€¦,CKsubscriptğ¶1â€¦subscriptğ¶ğ¾C_{1},\ldots,C_{K}, while it does not preclude a scenario that there might be another solution ofÂ (3) that may not exhibit this cluster structure. However, when each of the fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}â€™s is in addition assumed to be strictly convex, then {xiâ‹†}superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†\{x_{i}^{\star}\} is unique, and it necessarily has the clustered structure.

We next prove TheoremÂ 1.

Proof.

Theorem 1 guarantees the existence of a solution of (3) that exhibits the desired clustering structure. IV Algorithm for personalized federated learning

In this section, we introduce an algorithm to solve (3) in a federated server-users setting. The algorithm is adapted from the parallel direction method of multipliers (PDMM) inÂ [16].

We present here the approach with the larger number of variables and less coordination required. Abstracting details, PDMM proceeds as follows. First, it updates at each iteration t=0,1,â€¦ğ‘¡01â€¦t=0,1,\ldots, a randomly selected subset of primal variables {xi,ziâ€‹j}subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘—\{x_{i},z_{ij}\} by minimizing a surrogate of Lğ¿L with the rest of primal and dual variables fixed. Here, we apply and adapt PDMM to solve (IV), and hence, solve (3), in the federated server-users setting. To facilitate presentation of the algorithm, we enumerate all primal variables xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}â€™s and ziâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘—z_{ij}â€™s through a common index set ğ’®Psubscriptğ’®ğ‘ƒ\mathcal{S}_{P} with N2superscriptğ‘2N^{2} elements, such that the iğ‘–i-th element of ğ’®Psubscriptğ’®ğ‘ƒ\mathcal{S}_{P}, i=1,â€¦,Nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘i=1,\ldots,N, corresponds to xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}, and the remaining Nâ€‹(Nâˆ’1)ğ‘ğ‘1N(N-1) subsequent elements correspond to ziâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘—z_{ij}â€™s, where the ordered pairs â„“âˆ¼(i,j)similar-toâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘—\ell\sim(i,j) are positioned lexicographically in ğ’®Psubscriptğ’®ğ‘ƒ\mathcal{S}_{P}. The PDMM-based personalized FL method is shown in AlgorithmÂ 1.

Functions Biâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…)subscriptğµğ‘–â‹…â‹…B_{i}(\cdot,\cdot) in (3) and Biâ€‹jâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…)subscriptğµğ‘–ğ‘—â‹…â‹…B_{ij}(\cdot,\cdot) in (4) are instances of Bregman divergence, e.g., [16]; for example, they can be taken as Bâ€‹(u,v)=12â€‹â€–uâˆ’vâ€–2ğµğ‘¢ğ‘£12superscriptnormğ‘¢ğ‘£2B(u,v)=\frac{1}{2}\|u-v\|^{2}. The choice of functions Biâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…)subscriptğµğ‘–â‹…â‹…B_{i}(\cdot,\cdot) and Biâ€‹jâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…)subscriptğµğ‘–ğ‘—â‹…â‹…B_{ij}(\cdot,\cdot) also affect the computational cost of updates (3) and (4), respectively. For example, for Biâ€‹jâ€‹(u,v)=12â€‹â€–uâˆ’vâ€–2subscriptğµğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¢ğ‘£12superscriptnormğ‘¢ğ‘£2B_{ij}(u,v)=\frac{1}{2}\|u-v\|^{2}, updateÂ (4) corresponds to evaluating a proximal operator of the 2-norm that is done via block soft-thresholding. See also subsection 2.1 inÂ [16] for the choices of Biâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…)subscriptğµğ‘–â‹…â‹…B_{i}(\cdot,\cdot) that make update (3) computationally cheap. The positive parameters Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i} in (3) and Î·iâ€‹jsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–ğ‘—\eta_{ij} in (4) weigh the Bregman divergence terms; the larger Î·isubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–\eta_{i} is, the closer xi(t+1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡1x_{i}^{(t+1)} is to xi(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡x_{i}^{(t)}, i.e., the smaller steps the algorithm makes. A similar effect is achieved with Î·iâ€‹jsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–ğ‘—\eta_{ij} in (4). Quantity Î¼^iâ€‹j(t)superscriptsubscript^ğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡\widehat{\mu}_{ij}^{(t)} in (12) is an auxiliary dual variable associated with the dual variable Î¼iâ€‹j(t)superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡{\mu}_{ij}^{(t)}. The update step (12) is a backward dual step that is introduced for improving the algorithmâ€™s stability that may otherwise be violated due to the parallel and randomized nature of primal variable updates; seeÂ [16] for details. Similarly, parameters Ï„>0ğœ0\tau>0 and Î½>0ğœˆ0\nu>0 in (9) and (12), respectively, are â€œdampingâ€ factors in dual variable updates, that are again used to stabilize the algorithm trajectory.

With AlgorithmÂ 1â€™s initialization, we can set the ziâ€‹j(0)superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘—0z_{ij}^{(0)}â€™s, Î¼iâ€‹j(0)superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—0\mu_{ij}^{(0)}â€™s, and and Î¼^iâ€‹j(0)superscriptsubscript^ğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—0\widehat{\mu}_{ij}^{(0)}â€™s arbitrarily. For example, they can be all set to zero. For the initialization of the xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}â€™s, we need that xj(0)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—0x_{j}^{(0)}, jâ‰ iğ‘—ğ‘–j\neq i, is available at each user iğ‘–i. This can be achieved by, e.g., setting xi(0)=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–00x_{i}^{(0)}=0, for all iğ‘–i, or by letting the server send a common initial point y(0)âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptğ‘¦0superscriptâ„ğ‘‘y^{(0)}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} to all users prior to the algorithm start, so that each user iğ‘–i sets xi(0)=y(0)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–0superscriptğ‘¦0x_{i}^{(0)}=y^{(0)}. The initial pointÂ y(0)superscriptğ‘¦0y^{(0)} may also be obtained by (approximately) solving (1) via a (non-personalized, standard) FL algorithm, e.g., FedAvg.

With AlgorithmÂ 1, communication from users to the server (â€œuplinkâ€) takes place at steps (S5) and (S6). Note that, at each tğ‘¡t, during steps (S5) and (S6), the server receives exactly SPsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ƒS_{P} dÃ—1ğ‘‘1d\times 1-sized (real vectors) messages. Here, SPsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ƒS_{P} is the design parameter that can be taken to be much smaller than Nğ‘N, hence the uplink communication does not incur high overhead. Communication from the server to users (â€œdownlinkâ€) takes place at steps (S7) and (S10). At step (S7), the server brodcasts SDsubscriptğ‘†ğ·S_{D} dÃ—1ğ‘‘1d\times 1-sized messages. At step (S10), the server transmits a total of SDsubscriptğ‘†ğ·S_{D} dÃ—1ğ‘‘1d\times 1-sized messages to different users. (Specifically, variable Î¼iâ€‹j(t+1)superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡1\mu_{ij}^{(t+1)} is sent to user iğ‘–i, for â„“âˆ¼(i,j)similar-toâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘—\ell\sim(i,j), â„“âˆˆğ’®D(t)â„“superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ·ğ‘¡\ell\in{\mathcal{S}}_{D}^{(t)}.) Therefore, the downlink communication involves a total of (SP+SD)subscriptğ‘†ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘†ğ·(S_{P}+S_{D}) dÃ—1ğ‘‘1d\times 1-sized messages per iterationÂ tğ‘¡t. Quantity SDsubscriptğ‘†ğ·S_{D} is also a design parameter that can be set to be much smaller than Nğ‘N; hence, the downlink communication does not incur a significant communication overhead.

By applying TheoremÂ 3 in [16] it can be shown that, under appropriately chosen tuning parameters, ğ”¼â€‹[Fâ€‹(x(t))âˆ’Fâ‹†]=Oâ€‹(1/t)ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¹superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ¹â‹†ğ‘‚1ğ‘¡\mathbb{E}\left[F(x^{(t)})-F^{\star}\right]=O(1/t), where we recall that Fğ¹F is the objective function defined in (3), Fâ‹†=infxFâ€‹(x)superscriptğ¹â‹†subscriptinfimumğ‘¥ğ¹ğ‘¥F^{\star}=\inf_{x}F(x), and x(t)=((x1(t))âŠ¤,â€¦,(xN(t))âŠ¤)âŠ¤superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘¡topâ€¦superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¡toptopx^{(t)}=((x_{1}^{(t)})^{\top},\ldots,(x_{N}^{(t)})^{\top})^{\top} is generated by AlgorithmÂ 1.

V Numerical results

We now present numerical simulations. In the first set of experiments, we evaluate the cluster recovery abilities, as well as personalization and generalization abilities of the proposed formulation (3) and compare it with alternatives.

We now describe the first set of experiments. We consider a supervized binary classification problem. The generated data contains K=3ğ¾3K=3 clusters. For each cluster, for each given label/class (Â±1plus-or-minus1\pm 1), the data comes from a uniform distribution over an ellipse in â„2superscriptâ„2\mathbb{R}^{2}. The two ellipses that correspond to different classes for a given cluster overlap, so that the data in each cluster is not linearly separable. We generate 200 (training) data points from the distributions from each cluster, 100 points per class. Then, we associate to each cluster 20 FL users. Each FL user samples 10 data points out of the 200 data points available in its cluster. Hence, the data for all users within a cluster comes from the same distribution. Figure 1 illustrates the data, where different colors corresponds to different clusters, while the dashed lines represent optimal separators for each cluster, computed using the squared Hinge loss, i.e. the separators that minimize the squared Hinge loss over the full training data, for each cluster. The squared Hinge loss is used throughout the simulations, as the local loss function of each user iğ‘–i, and is given by

fi(x)=câ€‹â€–wâ€–22+1mâˆ‘j=1mmax{0,1âˆ’â„“iâ€‹j(âŸ¨w,aiâ€‹jâŸ©âˆ’b)}2,f_{i}(x)=\frac{c\|w\|^{2}}{2}+\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}\max\big{\{}0,1-\ell_{ij}(\langle w,a_{ij}\rangle-b)\big{\}}^{2},

where mğ‘šm represents the number of (local) data points, (aiâ€‹j,â„“iâ€‹j)j=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘—1ğ‘š(a_{ij},\ell_{ij})_{j=1}^{m}, represent the data points and class labels at user iğ‘–i, c>0ğ‘0c>0 is a penalty parameter that controls the regularization, while x=[w,b]âˆˆâ„d+1,d=2formulae-sequenceğ‘¥matrixğ‘¤ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘1ğ‘‘2x=\begin{bmatrix}w,b\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{d+1},\>d=2, represents the vector that defines the classifier. That is, the classifier based on vector x=[w,b]ğ‘¥matrixğ‘¤ğ‘x=\begin{bmatrix}w,b\end{bmatrix} takes a feature vector aâˆˆâ„2ğ‘superscriptâ„2a\in\mathbb{R}^{2} as input and predicts its label as â„“=signâ€‹(âŸ¨w,aâŸ©âˆ’b)â„“signğ‘¤ğ‘ğ‘\ell=\text{sign}(\langle w,a\rangle-b). Throughout the experiments, we set the parameter c=10âˆ’3ğ‘superscript103c=10^{-3}, in order to put more weight on the classification performance of the method.

We compare the proposed formulation (3) with the alternatives in (1), (2) and (4), referred to here as the global model, local models, and squared penalty, respectively. Formulation (1) corresponds to a standard, non-personalized FL solution. That is, the classifier vectors xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}â€™s with (1) are equal for all users, i.e., xi=yâˆ—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¦x_{i}=y^{*}, where we recall that yâˆ—superscriptğ‘¦y^{*} is the solution to (1). With formulation (2), each user iğ‘–iâ€™s classifier vector equals xi=yiâˆ—=argâ€‹minâ¡fiâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–argminsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥x_{i}=y_{i}^{*}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}f_{i}(x). In addition, we compare the proposed formulation (3) with an oracle model that knows beforehand the clustering structure of the users; then, for each user iğ‘–i within a cluster Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k}, the oracle lets user iğ‘–iâ€™s classifier vector be xi=argâ€‹minxâ€‹âˆ‘jâˆˆCkfkâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptargminğ‘¥subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ¶ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜ğ‘¥x_{i}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{x}\sum_{j\in C_{k}}f_{k}(x) We expect that the oracle model performs best in the considered setup among all methods, as it has an unfair advantage of knowing the cluster structure beforehand, and the data distributions of different clusters are very different, so data from a different cluster confuses another clusterâ€™s classifier. To evaluate solutions (1)-(4), we used CVXPY [20], [21].

In order to evaluate generalization and personalization abilities of different methods, we evaluate testing accuracy of the corresponding classifiers with respect to a newly generated test data. More precisely, let xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} be a classifier vector for user iğ‘–i obtained through training via any of the methods (1)-(4). For each user iğ‘–i, we then evaluate the testing accuracy of the classifier xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} with respect to the full testing data set for the cluster to which user iğ‘–i belongs to. We then average the testing accuracy across all users i=1,â€¦,Nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘i=1,\ldots,N. For each cluster, the testing data is generated by drawing new samples (new with respect to training data) from the same distributions according to which the training data is generated. Methods (3) or (4) then exhibit generalization if the average testing accuracy is above the average testing accuracy of local models; they exhibit personalization if their average testing accuracy is above that of the global model. The performance of the models, for different values of Î»ğœ†\lambda, is presented in Figure 2. Additionally, we present the average Euclidean distance between the classifier vectors xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}â€™s belonging to the same cluster. The results are summarized in Figure 3.

Figures 2 and 3 show the following. For Î»ğœ†\lambda sufficiently large, our method enforces consensus, and effectively performs as the standard FL method (1). For Î»ğœ†\lambda sufficiently small, the proposed method achieves both personalization, as it significantly outperforms the global model, as well as generalization, as the performance on the the complete cluster data is better than the strictly local models. Compared to the squared penalty model (4), we note that our method recovers the global model for sufficiently large Î»ğœ†\lambda, while the squared penalty method can recover the global model only asymptotically, as Î»ğœ†\lambda tends to infinity. The highest average accuracy is achieved by our method, being at 86.8%percent86.886.8\%, compared to the highest average accuracy of the squared penalty method, being at 86.6%percent86.686.6\%. Figure 3 shows that our method constantly produces more compact clusters, i.e. the average distance between solutions within clusters is constantly smaller than the one produced by the squared penalty method â€ â€ Note that the considered simulation setup is such that the inter cluster generalization does not help. That is, data distributions across different clusters are so far apart, that the oracle, that ignores the data from other clusters, works best. Clearly, if the data distributions across different clusters are very close, another oracle that exploits inter-cluster generalization may be considered. Consider the extreme case when the data distributions across the three clusters are mutually (almost) equal, i.e., the distribution difference is negligible, but this is not known beforehand. Then, clearly, the global model (1) becomes best-performing and an â€oracleâ€ model, in the sense that it implicitly utilizes the unknown cluster structure. Our formulation (3) can uncover this and actually match the global model for Î»ğœ†\lambda above a threshold, and hence perform optimally. On the other hand, (4) gets closer to the global model as Î»ğœ†\lambda increases, but never matches it. This illustration presents a scenario when there is clear merit in across-cluster generalization that the proposed formulation (3) is able to harness..

Hence, we can see that the proposed formulation (3) achieves a comparable or slightly better peak accuracy with respect to (4), while producing more compact models, i.e., significantly reducing the number of distinct models that need to be kept in the overall FL system. We report that the proposed model (3) exactly recovers the cluster structure (produces equal user models within clusters and finds 3 clusters) for Î»âˆˆ(0.0892,0.0919)ğœ†0.08920.0919\lambda\in(0.0892,0.0919).

Finally, we evaluated the performance of PDMM for solving (3). This result, as well as some additional numerical simulations, can be found in Appendix C.

VI Conclusion

We proposed a novel approach to personalized federated learning that, in addition to personalization and generalization, allows for clustering of usersâ€™ local models. The approach is based on a novel formulation of personalized FL wherein we minimize the sum of local usersâ€™ costs with respect to their local models, subject to a penalization term that penalizes the local modelsâ€™ differences via a sum-of-norms penalty. We prove exact cluster recovery guarantees for a general class of local usersâ€™ costs, assuming that the penalty parameterÂ Î»ğœ†\lambda that weighs the sum-of-norms penalty falls within an appropriately defined range. We further explicitly characterize this range in terms of within-clusters and across-clusters heterogeneity of local usersâ€™ costs (models). As an interesting byproduct, these results represent a direct generalization of convex clustering recovery guarantees for more general per-data point losses. Next, we propose an efficient algorithm based on the Parallel Direction Method of Multipliers (PDMM) to solve the proposed formulation in a federated server-users setting. Numerical experiments illustrate and corroborate the results.

Remark 3.

Note that, in (15), the right hand side also depends on Î»ğœ†\lambda through the wkâ‹†â€‹(Î»)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜â‹†ğœ†w_{k}^{\star}(\lambda). We can replace (15) with the following more conservative condition:

Î»<Î»Â¯:=mink,lâˆˆ[K],kâ‰ lâ¡min{wk}âˆˆğ’²â¡â€–âˆ‡gkâ€‹(wk)âˆ’âˆ‡glâ€‹(wk)â€–2â€‹maxkâˆˆ[K]â€‹âˆ‘lâ‰ knl,ğœ†Â¯ğœ†assignsubscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘˜ğ‘™delimited-[]ğ¾ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ’²normâˆ‡subscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ‘”ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜2subscriptğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾subscriptğ‘™ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘›ğ‘™\lambda<\overline{\lambda}:=\frac{\min_{k,l\in[K],k\neq l}\min_{\{w_{k}\}\in\mathcal{W}}\|\nabla g_{k}(w_{k})-\nabla g_{l}(w_{k})\|}{2\max_{k\in[K]}\sum_{l\neq k}n_{l}}, (26)

where set ğ’²âŠ‚â„dâ€‹Kğ’²superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ¾\mathcal{W}\subset{\mathbb{R}}^{d\,K} is defined inÂ (24).

Remark 4.

Note that, if Î»Â¯<Î»Â¯Â¯ğœ†Â¯ğœ†\underline{\lambda}<\overline{\lambda}, then, for any Î»âˆˆ(Î»Â¯,Î»Â¯)ğœ†Â¯ğœ†Â¯ğœ†\lambda\in(\underline{\lambda},\overline{\lambda}), both Theorems 1 and 2 hold, i.e., formulation (3) perfectly recovers the fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}â€™s cluster structure C1,â€¦,CKsubscriptğ¶1â€¦subscriptğ¶ğ¾C_{1},\ldots,C_{K}, and moreover the models wkâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜â‹†w_{k}^{\star}â€™s, k=1,â€¦,Kğ‘˜1â€¦ğ¾k=1,\ldots,K, that correspond to different clusters, are mutually distinct. Intuitively, condition Î»Â¯<Î»Â¯Â¯ğœ†Â¯ğœ†\underline{\lambda}<\overline{\lambda} requires that the (appropriately scaled) within-clusters function heterogeneity is smaller than the (appropriately scaled) between-clusters function heterogeneity.

In practice, we may not know quantities Î»Â¯Â¯ğœ†\underline{\lambda} and Î»Â¯Â¯ğœ†\overline{\lambda}. Similarly to convex clustering approaches, e.g. [22], we can solveÂ (3) for a set of values of the penalty parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda, {Î»(r)}superscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ\{\lambda^{(r)}\}, r=1,â€¦,Rğ‘Ÿ1â€¦ğ‘…r=1,\ldots,R, i.e., we can generate a solution path. In more detail, we can set Î»(r+1)=câ€‹Î»(r)superscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘superscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ\lambda^{(r+1)}=c\,\lambda^{(r)}, r=1,2,â€¦,ğ‘Ÿ12â€¦r=1,2,\ldots, for a small positive Î»(1)superscriptğœ†1\lambda^{(1)}, where c>1ğ‘1c>1 is a constant, and Rğ‘…R is the smallest index rğ‘Ÿr such that the number of distinct vectors xiâ‹†â€‹(Î»(R))superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptğœ†ğ‘…x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(R)}), i=1,â€¦,Nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘i=1,\ldots,N, is one.â€ â€ Note that we know that, for Î»â‰¥Î»^ğœ†^ğœ†\lambda\geq\widehat{\lambda}, for some Î»^>0^ğœ†0\widehat{\lambda}>0, all the xiâ‹†â€‹(Î»)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğœ†x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda)â€™s coincideÂ [17]. Hence, all the xiâ‹†â€‹(Î»)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğœ†x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda)â€™s are necessarily mutually equal for a certain Î»(R)superscriptğœ†ğ‘…\lambda^{(R)}, for some finiteÂ R>0ğ‘…0R>0. When solvingÂ (3) for Î»=Î»(r+1)ğœ†superscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ1\lambda=\lambda^{(r+1)}, the numerical solver ofÂ (3) (e.g., see ahead AlgorithmÂ 1) can use warm start, i.e., it can be initialized with {xiâ‹†â€‹(Î»(r))}superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ\{x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(r)})\}. The resulting solution path {xiâ‹†â€‹(Î»(r))}superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ\{x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(r)})\}, r=1,â€¦,Rğ‘Ÿ1â€¦ğ‘…r=1,\ldots,R, will typically have a non-increasing number of mutually distinct models xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}â€™s, with Nğ‘N distinct models for Î»(1)superscriptğœ†1\lambda^{(1)} and a sufficiently small Î»(1)superscriptğœ†1\lambda^{(1)}, and one distinct model forÂ Î»(R)superscriptğœ†ğ‘…\lambda^{(R)}.

If, for a certain value rğ‘Ÿr (or for a range of values rğ‘Ÿr), we have that Î»(r)âˆˆ(Î»Â¯,Î»Â¯)superscriptğœ†ğ‘ŸÂ¯ğœ†Â¯ğœ†\lambda^{(r)}\in(\underline{\lambda},\overline{\lambda}) and there holds Î»Â¯<Î»Â¯Â¯ğœ†Â¯ğœ†\underline{\lambda}<\overline{\lambda} (a hidden cluster structure exists), then solution {xiâ‹†â€‹(Î»(r))}superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ\{x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(r)})\} satisfies Theorems 1 and 2, i.e., the hidden cluster structure is uncovered. For a fixed Î»(r)superscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ\lambda^{(r)}, we can check whether the hidden cluster structure is uncovered in an â€œa posterioriâ€ way as follows. We first fix the clustering C1=C1â€‹(Î»(r)),â€¦,CK=CKâ€‹(Î»(r))formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶1superscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿâ€¦subscriptğ¶ğ¾subscriptğ¶ğ¾superscriptğœ†ğ‘ŸC_{1}=C_{1}(\lambda^{(r)}),\ldots,C_{K}=C_{K}(\lambda^{(r)}) induced by {xiâ‹†â€‹(Î»(r))}superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ\{x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(r)})\}, and then we check whether conditionsÂ (25) and (26) hold.

Even when we are not directly concerned with uncovering the hidden cluster structure in the sense of TheoremsÂ 1 and 2, there are several merits of computing the solution path, similarly to the convex clustering scenario, e.g.,Â [22]. For example, depending on the requirements of a given application, we can select the index rğ‘Ÿr, i.e., the model {xiâ‹†â€‹(Î»(r))}superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ\{x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(r)})\} for which the number of distinct xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}â€™s (closely) matches the need of the current application. Furthermore, increasing Î»ğœ†\lambda translates into improving the degree of generalization and reducing the degree of personalization, so one can select the appropriate {xiâ‹†â€‹(Î»(r))}superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿ\{x_{i}^{\star}(\lambda^{(r)})\} according to the current application needs.

Remark 5.

Note that conditions (27) and (28) can be interpreted as measures of within-cluster homogeneity and between-cluster heterogeneity, respectively. Remark 6.

Theorem 3 states that the clustering structure of the solution is maintained, for any choice of Î»ğœ†\lambda satisfying (29). Compared to the results from Theorems 1 and 2, the resulting interval (if existent) is smaller, but the lower and upper bounds are independent of Î»ğœ†\lambda, and of the optimal solutions of problem (5).

Remark 7.

Compared with (25) and (26), while possibly smaller, the interval (29) provides a more natural interpretation: if the between-cluster heterogeneity is sufficiently larger than the within-cluster homogeneity, so the interval (29) is non-empty, a (strong) clustering structure among users exists, and can be recovered by (3).

Remark 8.

Theorem 4 shows that optimal models of users belonging to the same clusters are at least Ïµ~~italic-Ïµ\tilde{\epsilon} close, with optimal models of users belonging to different clusters being at least Î´~~ğ›¿\tilde{\delta} apart. Here, Ïµ~=maxkâˆˆ[K]â¡ÏµkÎ¼~italic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘˜ğœ‡\tilde{\epsilon}=\max_{k\in[K]}\frac{\epsilon_{k}}{\mu}, and Î´~=minkâ‰ lâ¡Î´kâ€‹lL~ğ›¿subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜ğ‘™ğ¿\tilde{\delta}=\min_{k\neq l}\frac{\delta_{kl}}{L}. In the case that Ïµ~<Î´~~italic-Ïµ~ğ›¿\tilde{\epsilon}<\tilde{\delta}, the clustering structure implied by Theorem 4 is strong, in the sense that the local optima corresponding to different clusters are well separated.

Remark 9.

In the case that Ïµ~<Î´~~italic-Ïµ~ğ›¿\tilde{\epsilon}<\tilde{\delta} and the interval given by (29) is non-empty, Theorems 3 and 4 show that a natural clustering structure among the userâ€™s costs exists. In addition, the proposed formulation (3) uncovers the said structure, for any Î»ğœ†\lambda in a range that is independent of the optimal solutions of problem (5).

We now prove Theorem 4

Proof.

From Assumption 3, for iâˆˆCkğ‘–subscriptğ¶ğ‘˜i\in C_{k}, jâˆˆClğ‘—subscriptğ¶ğ‘™j\in C_{l}, kâ‰ lğ‘˜ğ‘™k\neq l, and for all xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, we have

Î´kâ€‹lâ‰¤â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fjâ€‹(x)â€–.subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜ğ‘™normâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥\displaystyle\delta_{kl}\leq\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{j}(x)\|.

In particular, for x=xiâ€ ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â€ x=x_{i}^{\dagger}, we have

Appendix C Additional experiments

Here, we present some additional experiments. First, we evaluate the clustering recovery of (3) and compare it with (4). The data is generated using the same methodology described in Section V, with each ellipse containing 100100100 data points, hence each cluster contains a total of 200200200 data points. The dataset is shown in Figure 4. We generate n=10ğ‘›10n=10 users per cluster, and each user samples 85%percent8585\% of points from the cluster it belongs to, ensuring the resulting models will be similar for users within clusters. The performance of (3) and (4) is evaluated for different values of the penalty parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda, belonging to {1000,1,0.12,0.08,0.05,0.03,0.02,0.01}100010.120.080.050.030.020.01\{1000,1,0.12,0.08,0.05,0.03,0.02,0.01\}. The dashed lines in the figures correspond to optimal separators for each cluster, evaluated on the full data. The full lines represent model estimates corresponding to (3) and (4). The results are presented in Figure 6.

We can see that Figure 6 corroborates the results from Theorems 1 and 2. In particular, for Î»ğœ†\lambda sufficiently large, our method produces only one model across all users. For Î»ğœ†\lambda higher than, but close to the theoretical upper bound from Theorem 2, the method produces two models across all the users (second row, left image). Finally, for Î»ğœ†\lambda within the theoretical range, our method produces exactly three models, uncovering the clustering structure. We remark that, while the produced models are not optimal for the training data, they can still be used as a guideline: if a clustering solution is obtained, and the parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda falls within the theoretical bounds suggested by Theorems 1 and 2, an innate clustering structure is uncovered, and the users that are selected in the clusters can focus on training their models within the cluster of similar users. Moreover, the left image in the third row suggests that the bounds obtained by Theorems 1 and 2 are somewhat conservative - the proposed method produced 3 models across users, for Î»ğœ†\lambda that is lower than the theoretical lower bound, meaning that in practice, the clustering structure can be recovered for a wider range of Î»ğœ†\lambda than predicted by theory.

In the second experiment, we present the convergence results of PDMM for solving the proposed method in federated settings. The dataset and the parameters are the same as was described in the setting above. For PDMM in the federated settings, in each iteration we randomly select a subset of users, being 40%percent4040\% of the total users. The PDMM tuning parameters are selected as Ï=10,Î·=10,Ï„=45,Î½=15formulae-sequenceğœŒ10formulae-sequenceğœ‚10formulae-sequenceğœ45ğœˆ15\rho=10,\>\eta=10,\>\tau=\frac{4}{5},\>\nu=\frac{1}{5}. The Bregman divergence in PDMM is set to be the squared Euclidean distance. All variables in PDMM (primal and dual) are initialized to zero vectors.

We evaluate the cost function in (3) achieved by PDMM at each iteration tğ‘¡t. We also evaluate the optimal value of the cost in (3) via CVXPY. We then plot the difference (optimality gap) along iterations. To evaluate the performance of PDMM for (3), we used the primal variables xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}â€™s. In particular, we plot Fâ€‹(x(t))âˆ’Fâˆ—ğ¹superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ¹F(x^{(t)})-F^{*}, where Fğ¹F is the objective defined in (3) and Fâˆ—superscriptğ¹F^{*} denotes the optimal value of Fğ¹F, computed via CVXPY. The parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda is set to 0.02.0.020.02. The results are presented in Figure 5.

While this is not pursued here, we remark that it is possible to reduce AlgorithmÂ 1 complexity by dynamically (over iterations) exploiting the clustered structure of a solution toÂ (3). Namely, note that, for a solution {xiâ‹†}superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†\{x_{i}^{\star}\} of (3), if xiâ‹†=xjâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†x_{i}^{\star}=x_{j}^{\star} for some iâ‰ jğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq j, then ziâ€‹jâ‹†=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘—â‹†0z_{ij}^{\star}=0. This may be exploited in the algorithm implementation as follows: once user iğ‘–i detects that ziâ€‹j(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡z_{ij}^{(t)} is close to zero over a range of consecutive iterations, it can cease updating ziâ€‹j(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡z_{ij}^{(t)} and cease communicating it to the server, and it can also replace locally xj(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘¡x_{j}^{(t)} with xi(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡x_{i}^{(t)} in its subsequent updates. This also translates into reducing the communication cost at the server side, as xj(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘¡x_{j}^{(t)} no longer needs to be communicated to userÂ iğ‘–i. In this way, storage, computational, and communication costs may be dynamically reduced as the algorithm evolves.
